message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to abduct the right arm above 90 degrees, asymmetrical shoulders, and scapular protrusion suggest that the injury is to the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle responsible for stabilizing the scapula during shoulder motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient underwent lymph node dissection, which can lead to damage to the long thoracic nerve, leading to winged scapula and inability to abduct the arm above 90 degrees. The other nerves listed do not innervate the serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for these functions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to abduct the arm above 90 degrees and protrusion of the medial aspect of the scapula suggests an injury to the long thoracic nerve, which supplies the serratus anterior muscle that stabilizes the scapula during arm movement. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus would cause Erb's palsy, which affects shoulder abduction and external rotation. The suprascapular nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which help shoulder abduction and external rotation. The thoracodorsal nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is responsible for shoulder adduction, extension, and medial rotation, and would not cause the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's inability to abduct her right arm above 90 degrees and protrusion of the medial aspect of the right scapula suggest injury to the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle responsible for scapular stabilization during arm abduction. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus would most likely affect the entire upper extremity, while injury to the suprascapular nerve would specifically affect shoulder external rotation and abduction. Injury to the thoracodorsal nerve would affect latissimus dorsi muscle function, but this would not cause shoulder asymmetry and scapular protrusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the injury is to the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle and plays a crucial role in the abduction of the arm above the horizontal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest injury to the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle responsible for scapular movement and stability. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus would affect multiple branches and result in more extensive deficits. Suprascapular nerve injury would cause weakness in the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. Injury to the thoracodorsal nerve would result in weakness of the latissimus dorsi muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to abduct the right arm above 90 degrees and protrusion of the medial aspect of the right scapula suggest injury to the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle that helps elevate the arm. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus would affect the entire upper extremity. Suprascapular nerve injury would primarily affect shoulder abduction and external rotation, not the scapular winging seen here. Thoracodorsal nerve injury would affect the latissimus dorsi muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms indicate a condition called winged scapula, which is caused by injury or compression of the long thoracic nerve. The other options do not innervate the serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for stabilizing the scapula.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to abduct the right arm above 90 degrees and the protrusion of the medial aspect of the right scapula indicates winging of the scapula, which is primarily caused by damage to the long thoracic nerve. The other options are not associated with this specific symptomatology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest injury to the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle that stabilizes the scapula during arm abduction. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus or the suprascapular nerve would cause weakness in other muscles such as the deltoid or rotator cuff. Injury to the thoracodorsal nerve would cause weakness in the latissimus dorsi muscle.
